query.result:
1 ‘God, the nations have come’, alternating 2 or three or four sweet psalmody, 3 the women began, and weeping;
4 and Beatrice, sighing and pious, 5 she listened to them so made, that little 6 more to the cross changed Mary.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
7 Ma poi che l’altre vergini dier loco 8 a lei di dir, levata dritta in pè, 9 rispuose, colorata come foco:
10 ‘Modicum, et non videbitis me; 11 et iterum, sorelle mie dilette, 12 modicum, et vos videbitis me’.
query.result:
7 But then that the other virgins gave her place, 8 to her to say, raised straight on foot, 9 she answered, colored like fire:
10 “A little, and you will not see me; 11 and again, my beloved sisters, 12 a little, and you will see me.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
13 Poi le si mise innanzi tutte e sette, 14 e dopo sé, solo accennando, mosse 15 me e la donna e ’l savio che ristette.
query.result: 13 Then she set herself before all seven, 14 and after herself, only by a hint, moved 15 me and the woman and the wise one who remained.

16 Thus it went; and I do not believe that it was 17 the tenth of his step placed on earth, 18 when with the eyes the eyes struck me;
19 and with tranquil aspect “Come sooner”, 20 he said to me, “as long as, if I speak with you, 21 to listen to me you may be well disposed”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
22 Sì com’ io fui, com’ io dovëa, seco, 23 dissemi: «Frate, perché non t’attenti 24 a domandarmi omai venendo meco?».
query.result: 22 Thus as I was, as I ought to be, with him, 23 he/she said to me: “Brother, why do you not pay attention 24 to ask me now, coming with me?”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
25 Come a color che troppo reverenti 26 dinanzi a suo maggior parlando sono, 27 che non traggon la voce viva ai denti,
28 avvenne a me, che sanza intero suono 29 incominciai: «Madonna, mia bisogna 30 voi conoscete, e ciò ch’ad essa è buono».
query.result:
25 Like to those who are too reverent 26 before his greater speaking are, 27 who do not draw the living voice to the teeth,
28 it happened to me, that without a complete sound 29 I began: “Madonna, my need 30 you know, and that which to her is good.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
31 Ed ella a me: «Da tema e da vergogna 32 voglio che tu omai ti disviluppe, 33 sì che non parli più com’ om che sogna.
query.result: 31 And she to me: “From fear and from shame 32 I want that you now uncoil yourself, 33 so that you no longer speak as a man who dreams.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
34 Sappi che ’l vaso che ’l serpente ruppe, 35 fu e non è; ma chi n’ha colpa, creda 36 che vendetta di Dio non teme suppe.
query.result: 34 Sappi che ’l vaso che ’l serpente ruppe, 35 fu e non è; ma chi n’ha colpa, creda 36 che vendetta di Dio non teme suppe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
37 Non sarà tutto tempo sanza reda 38 l’aguglia che lasciò le penne al carro, 39 per che divenne mostro e poscia preda;
40 ch’io veggio certamente, e però il narro, 41 a darne tempo già stelle propinque, 42 secure d’ogn’ intoppo e d’ogne sbarro,
43 nel quale un cinquecento diece e cinque, 44 messo di Dio, anciderà la fuia 45 con quel gigante che con lei delinque.

query.result:
46 And perhaps that my dark narration, 47 as Themis and Sphinx, but it persuades you less, 48 because in their way the intellect dulls it;
49 but soon fierce the deeds the Naiads, 50 that will solve this strong enigma 51 without damage of sheep or of biade.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
52 Tu nota; e sì come da me son porte, 53 così queste parole segna a’ vivi 54 del viver ch’è un correre a la morte.
query.result: 52 You note; and so as from me are doors, 53 thus these words mark to the living 54 of life that is a running to death.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
55 E aggi a mente, quando tu le scrivi, 56 di non celar qual hai vista la pianta 57 ch’è or due volte dirubata quivi.
query.result: 55 And add to mind, when you write them, 56 not to hide what you have seen the plant 57 which is now twice plundered here.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
58 Qualunque ruba quella o quella schianta, 59 con bestemmia di fatto offende a Dio, 60 che solo a l’uso suo la creò santa.
query.result: 58 Whatever steals that one or that one shatters, 59 with blasphemy of fact offends God, 60 who only for its use created it holy.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
61 Per morder quella, in pena e in disio 62 cinquemilia anni e più l’anima prima 63 bramò colui che ’l morso in sé punio.
query.result: 61 To bite that, in pain and in desire 62 five thousand years and more the soul before 63 desired he who the bite in himself punished

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
64 Dorme lo ’ngegno tuo, se non estima 65 per singular cagione esser eccelsa 66 lei tanto e sì travolta ne la cima.
query.result: 64 Your intellect sleeps, if it does not esteem 65 for a singular cause to be exalted 66 she so much and so overwhelmed in the summit

query.result:
67 And if states were not water of Elsa, 68 the thoughts vain around your mind, 69 and the pleasure for them a Piramo to the elm,

query.result:
73 But why I see you in the intellect 74 made of stone and, obtained, tinted, 75 so that the light of my saying dazzles you,
76 I also want, and if not written, at least painted, 77 that it carries you within yourself for that 78 that the bound palm staff is brought.

query.result: 79 And I: “Just as wax from sealing, 80 that the impressed figure does not change, 81 marked is now by you my brain.

82 Ma perché tanto sovra mia veduta 83 vostra parola disïata vola, 84 che più la perde quanto più s’aiuta?».
query.result: 82 But why so much over my sight 83 your word disïata flies, 84 that the more it loses, the more it helps itself?

85 “Why you know,” he said, “that school 86 that you have followed it, and you see its doctrine 87 how can follow my word;
88 and you see your way from the divine 89 to be as distant as it disagrees 90 from earth the sky that hurries the higher.”

query.prompt:

103 E più corusco e con più lenti passi 104 teneva il sole il cerchio di merigge, 105 che qua e là, come li aspetti, fassi,
106 quando s’affisser, sì come s’affigge 107 chi va dinanzi a gente per iscorta 108 se trova novitate o sue vestigge,
109 le sette donne al fin d’un’ombra smorta, 110 qual sotto foglie verdi e rami nigri 111 sovra suoi freddi rivi l’alpe porta.
query.result:
103 And more glittering and with slower steps 104 the sun held the circle of meridians, 105 that here and there, as you expect them, you make,
106 when it appears, just as it appears 107 who goes before people for a short distance 108 if he finds novelty or his traces,
109 the seven women at the end of a faded shadow, 110 as under green leaves and black branches 111 over its cold streams the alpine gate.

Please translate each line literally into English.

query.result: 112 Before them Euphrates and Tigers 113 to see seemed to me to emerge from a fountain, 114 and, as if friends, to part lazily.

query.prompt:

115 «O luce, o gloria de la gente umana, 116 che acqua è questa che qui si dispiega 117 da un principio e sé da sé lontana?».
query.result: 115 “O light, O glory of the human people, 116 what water is this that here unfolds 117 from a beginning and itself from itself distant?”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
118 Per cotal priego detto mi fu: «Priega 119 Matelda che ’l ti dica». E qui rispuose, 120 come fa chi da colpa si dislega,
121 la bella donna: «Questo e altre cose 122 dette li son per me; e son sicura 123 che l’acqua di Letè non gliel nascose».
query.result:
118 For such a prayer said to me: “Pray 119 Matelda that she may tell it to you.” And here she answered, 120 as one does who disassociates from guilt,
121 the beautiful lady: “This and other things 122 said are for me; and I am certain 123 that the water of Lethe has not hidden them from him.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
124 E Bëatrice: «Forse maggior cura, 125 che spesse volte la memoria priva, 126 fatt’ ha la mente sua ne li occhi oscura.
query.result: 124 And Beatrice: “Perhaps greater care, 125 that often memory deprives, 126 has made its mind in the eyes dark.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
127 Ma vedi Eünoè che là diriva: 128 menalo ad esso, e come tu se’ usa, 129 la tramortita sua virtù ravviva».
query.result: 127 But see Eunoè who there will say: 128 lead him to it, and as you are accustomed, 129 revive his waned virtue.

130 Like a gentle soul, who makes no excuse, 131 but makes his will of another's will, 132 as soon as it is, for a sign, outward opened;
133 so, after I was taken from her, 134 the beautiful woman moved me, and to Statius 135 feminine‑ly said: “Come with him.”

136 If I had, reader, a longer space 137 to write, I would still sing in part 138 the sweet drink that never would satisfy me;
139 but because all the pages are full 140 arranged to this second song, 141 the brake of art no longer lets me go.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
142 Io ritornai da la santissima onda 143 rifatto sì come piante novelle 144 rinovellate di novella fronda,
145 puro e disposto a salire a le stelle.
query.result:
142 I returned from the most holy wave 143 refashioned so as new plants 144 renewed with new foliage,
145 pure and disposed to rise to the stars.
